physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Skin lesions were described as violaceous, ulcerated with infarcted necrotic areas, and located in the inguinal and axillary regions. Blood tests showed leukopenia (WBC count, 2460/μL) and neutropenia (neutrophil count, 220/μL).
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Lesions progressed to become ulcerated within 3 to 4 days, necessitating surgical debridement due to worsening condition.

physical_examinations.vital_signs: CD4+ cell count: 4770/μL; neutrophil count increased to 2810/μL.
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Skin lesions improved with antipseudomonal antibiotic therapy. CD4+ and immunoglobulin levels were normal.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The neutrophil count increased from 220/μL to 2810/μL, and skin lesions improved following treatment with piperacillin sodium and tazobactam sodium.

physical_examinations.vital_signs: HIV viral load reduced to 2403 copies/mL (3.38 log10 copies/mL).
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Fourth-generation ELISA for HIV was positive for the mother.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The HIV viral load was higher than 7.0 log10 copies/mL initially and reduced significantly after 6 weeks of highly active antiretroviral therapy.
